scenes.background: You are leading a project team that has just received an urgent assignment requiring a significant amount of work to be completed within a tight deadline. The team is feeling a lot of pressure, and morale is low, with some members showing signs of frustration and anxiety. One of your team members, Lisa, says: 'I don't think we can meet this deadline. It's just too much work in too little time.' You responded by acknowledging the difficulty and suggesting to prioritize tasks and see if additional resources are needed. As the team begins to break down the tasks, [Monica] seems hesitant and [Bob] looks frustrated.
scenes.description: [Monica] sighs and says to [Bob]: 'I still feel like we're going to miss the deadline, even with the prioritized tasks.' [Bob] responds with a hint of frustration: 'Honestly, this whole prioritizing thing just feels like rearranging deck chairs on the Titanic.'

options.text: Let's stay focused on what we can control. We can only do our best given the circumstances.
options.analysis: You maintained a calm approach and emphasized focusing on the tasks at hand, showing good emotional regulation but could improve on interpersonal balance.

options.text: I understand your concerns, but let's take it one step at a time. We might surprise ourselves.
options.analysis: You acknowledged the team's concerns while encouraging perseverance, showing good emotional perception and interpersonal balance.

options.text: If anyone has a better idea, I'm open to hearing it. Otherwise, let's stick to the plan.
options.analysis: You invited alternative suggestions, showing good communication skills, but the emotional perception and social skills could be improved.
